function_call.name: get_risks
function_call.arguments: {"risks":[{"Description":"Increasing connectivity between green areas in modern cities could facilitate the spread of infectious diseases between geographically distant rat populations.","Impact":"Increased risk of infectious diseases spreading to urban areas, posing a threat to human and animal health.","Mitigation":"Implement control measures for rodent populations and monitor the spread of infectious diseases in urban areas.","Technologies":"Remote monitoring systems, rodent control methods, and disease surveillance techniques.","People":"Urban residents, domestic animals, wildlife, and public health officials.","Owner":"Public health authorities, urban planners, and wildlife conservation organizations."},{"Description":"The increase in biodiversity of rodent predators may foster the introduction of certain pathogens into urban landscapes.","Impact":"Risks of introducing new pathogens into urban areas, leading to potential transmission to humans, pets, and wildlife.","Mitigation":"Implement measures to monitor and manage the biodiversity of rodent predators, conduct regular disease surveillance, and educate the public about potential risks.","Technologies":"DNA sequencing for pathogen detection, wildlife monitoring technologies, and public health communication platforms.","People":"Urban residents, pet owners, wildlife conservationists, and public health authorities.","Owner":"Public health organizations, wildlife conservation groups, and local government agencies."},{"Description":"The presence of foxes in urban areas has increased the likelihood of the small fox tapeworm (E. multilocularis) occurring in city rodents and infection risk for domestic dogs and cats.","Impact":"Increased risk of E. multilocularis infection in urban rodents, domestic dogs, and cats, posing a threat to public health.","Mitigation":"Implement control measures for fox populations, conduct regular surveillance for tapeworm infection in urban areas, and educate pet owners about potential risks.","Technologies":"GPS tracking for fox monitoring, tapeworm screening tools, and public awareness campaigns.","People":"Pet owners, urban residents, wildlife conservationists, and public health officials.","Owner":"Public health authorities, animal control agencies, and wildlife management organizations."}]}
